unit_learning_outcomes.description: Research and interpret texts, using appropriate historiographical approaches to analysis.
Demonstrate understanding of principal historiographical approaches to the texts of key ancient historians.
Identify, critically assess and evaluate approaches to the writing of ancient history.
Communicate effectively with teaching staff and peers, demonstrating an informed respect for professional (academic) and ethical principles and values.

non_scheduled_learning_activities.description: Each week you will post responses to the questions set on the weekly topics. You should also respond to at least two posts by other students.
Each week there are set readings from the ancient sources and the modern historiographers for you complete

assessments.assessment_title: Critical Evaluation of your weekly posts.
assessments.description: Compose a reflective, critical evaluation of your engagement with the unit's topics in your weekly posts: your word limit for this task is 1500 words. Further details on this task are on the unit's ilearn page.
A short written paper that requires historiographical analysis: your word limit is 1500 words.  Further details on this task are on the unit's ilearn page.

This is a longer written assessment task: your word limit is 2500 words. 
Further details on this task are on the unit's ilearn page.

data.subject_search_title: AHIS8210 - History Writing in Antiquity: Herodotus and Thucydides
data.description: In antiquity Herodotus was regarded as the father of history. Thucydides is widely acknowledged as the creator of political history. This unit examines a range of historiographical approaches to the reading of these two influential Greek historians. The aim of this unit is both to understand Herodotus and Thucydides as writers and to evaluate the different historiographical approaches taken by the modern scholars who have studied them.
